Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Role of Lesson Study in K-12 Mathematics and Science Teacher Education
Award.AbstractNarration: This conference will shed light on how mathematics and science teacher educators are currently using lesson study to prepare pre-service teachers. Lesson study is a structured process for teachers to study content and curriculum, carefully plan lessons to test a researchable question about student learning, teach the lesson in front of other professionals who help gather data, and use that data to evaluate the efficacy of the instruction for the students. With its focus on researching the connection between lesson enactment and student learning, lesson study contains structures for connecting practice-based teacher education to schools and classrooms. By evaluating the efficacy of the instruction, the outcomes, positive or negative, can be applied to other relevant instruction. The use of lesson study in college classes for pre-service teachers is relatively new in the United States, but it is becoming more popular. Because lesson study has been used primarily for in-service professional development of teachers, little is known about how it can be optimally employed for pre-service teacher education. This project will improve teacher educators' understanding of how lesson study can be optimized to teach pre-service teachers which will help bring this technique to the future teachers in their programs. When pre-service teachers are better prepared, high quality mathematics and science instruction may be expanded to more schools, giving more K-12 students improved opportunities to learn these subjects. <br/><br/>This project will support twenty-four mathematics and science teacher educators to collaborate in identifying their pedagogical goals for using lesson study and the enabling and constraining factors for its implementation that they perceive. Given that universities and schools have variance in their structures and focus, teacher educators will identify any modifications they have made to the lesson study process considering their context. By collaboratively identifying pedagogical goals, enabling and constraining implementation factors, and evidence-based adjustments to the lesson study process, this project will clarify the lesson study practices of the participants. The project will yield an edited book for other teacher educators to deploy lesson study in their teacher education programs, building from what is currently known and setting a trajectory for future pre-service teacher lesson study and research. Additionally, the project will establish a baseline network of teacher educators using lesson study within teacher education that can be built upon in the future. The Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics by preK-12 students and teachers, through the research and development of new innovations and approaches. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for the projects.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a one-year grant within the Teaching strand of DRK-12. We designed and implemented a working conference for teacher educators. Teacher educators work with future teachers, often referred to as Pre-Service Teachers (PSTs). Our goal was to identify current lesson study practices in pre-service mathematics and science teacher (MST) education and connect them to research about how teachers learn best. We know from other research that teachers need a well-developed set of methods to help a diverse student body develop their science and mathematics knowledge.


Lesson study is an organized method for teachers to work together to plan lessons that they think will enhance the quality of learning for their students. Within lesson study, these carefully planned lessons are called research lessons. This is because, unlike some other methods for teacher learning, the teachers observe students as the planned lesson is taught. When the research lesson is over, the teachers use the evidence they gathered from their observations to determine if the lesson, and their reasons for developing it the way they did, were sound. From this evaluation, the teachers can determine how their learning from the research lesson applies to future lessons they will teach.


In this conference, we brought together 31 teacher educators from the United States who are using lesson study to prepare their PSTs. Attendees included early-, mid-, and late-career researchers, doctoral students, and select practitioners from several geographic regions of the US. During the conference, which was called the Lesson Study in Mathematics and Science Teacher Education Conference (LSMSTEC), we identified the goals teacher educators have for using lesson study in pre-service education, catalogued the breadth and depth of current practice with lesson study, and identified factors that make the use of lesson study with PSTs either easier or more difficult. Through this work, we built new knowledge about how to develop PK-12 STEM students’ knowledge and teaching skills.


The overall outcomes of this project were threefold. First, the project supported the development and enactment of the conference. Second, the conference generated a network of teacher educators using lesson study to improve the training of future math science teachers. This network is now researching how to further use lesson study in the development of future teachers. Third, the project culminated with the creation of a proposal for a peer-edited book about how US teacher educators use lesson study in MST education. The book will include contributions from 30 of the 31 conference participants and will be targeted to an audience of other teacher educators.
